column5: a disposition to elicit minimal or no biological response when in contact with tissue or implanted
column10: non-toxic and non-immunogenic, with little or no bonding or integration with the body.

column5: a biocompatibility and gradually degrading and being resorbed by the body over time
column9: being absorbed or excreted as it performs its function, often eliminating the need for removal.

column5: steel is a ferrous metal that consists of iron and carbon and possibly other alloying elements (and possibly impurities).
ferrous metal that has a limited amout of carbon
stainless steel is an iron-based alloy that contains chromium, making it resistant to corrosion (rust).
metal that has iron as primary constituent
ferrous metal that has an amout of min 2.07 wt % carbon
a metallic alloy is a mixture of chemical elements of which at least one is a metallic element

chromium steel is the name for any one of a class of non-stainless steels which are used for applications such as bearings, tools, drills and utensils. Such as stainless steel, chromium steels contain chromium, but do not have the corrosion-resistant properties of stainless steel.
steel with tailored mechanical properties
alloy steel is steel that is alloyed with a variety of elements in amounts between 1.0% and 50% by weight, typically to improve its mechanical properties.
non-ferrous metals are metals or alloys that do not contain iron (allotropes of iron, ferrite, and so on) in appreciable amounts.
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of aluminium mixed with other elements
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of copper combined with other elements
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of titanium combined with other elements
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of nickel combined with other elements
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of zinc combined with other elements
metal that are rare, naturally occurring, and have high economic value due to their resistance to corrosion, oxidation, and chemical reaction
precious metal consisting primarily of gold
precious metal consisting primarily of silver
precious metal consisting primarily of platinum
precious metal consisting primarily of palladium
precious metal consisting primarily of rhodium

poylethylen is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer ethylene including further crosslinking and modifications using other comonomers; it excludes ultra hight molecular polyethylen.
poylpropylene is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer propylene including further crosslinking and modifications using other comonomers
column9: this excludes ultra hight molecular polyethylen because very high molecular weight polyethylene is not thermoplastic anymore

column5: polyvinyl chloride is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer vinyl chloride.
column9: they are usualy hard or soft and flexible with incrased use of plasticisers.

column5: polystyrene is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer aromatic hydrocarbon
Polyethylene terephthalate is a thermoplastic polyester produced by polycondensation of ethylene glycol and terephthalate precursors.
column10: it is the dominant polyester utilized in global packaging and fiber applications

column5: A biodegradable thermolpastic polyester polymer; synthesized via the polycondensation of succinic acid and 1,4-butanediol.
Epoxy resins are epoxide-functional oligomers curing via ring-opening into crosslinked thermoset networks.
column10: they are utilized for high-performance structural adhesives, composite matrices, and protective coatings.

column5: Phenolic resins are thermosetting polymers synthesized via condensation of phenol and formaldehyde
column9: they form rigid, char-forming crosslinked networks
column10: they are utilized for flame-resistant adhesives, friction materials, and molded components

column5: Melamine resin is a thermosetting aminoplast polymer synthesized via condensation
column9: they form hard, durable crosslinked networks.
column10: they are widely used in decorative laminates, kitchenware, and coating crosslinkers.

column5: Polyurethanes are a polymer family defined by urethane linkages, formed by reacting polyisocyanates with polyols
column10: they are it offers high versatility in mechanical properties

column5: Unsaturated polyester resin is a thermosetting polymer system of unsaturated polyester prepolymers in reactive vinyl monomers; it cures by radical crosslinking into rigid networks.
column10: they are used for fiber-reinforced composites

column5: Natural rubber is an elastomer polymer, and a biopolymer harvested as plant latex; consisting of cis-1,4-polyisoprene chains; typically sulfur-vulcanized to create crosslinks between chains.
column9: they are predominantly cis-1,4-polyisoprene,
column10: they are used widely in Heavy-duty truck tires

column5: Styrene–butadiene rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic random copolymer elastomers of styrene and butadiene, made by emulsion or solution polymerization and typically vulcanized.
column10: used widely for its good abrasion resistance and tunable hardness, for instance in tire treads.

column5: Silicone rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a crosslinked polysiloxane elastomer family, with organic side groups.
column9: it is available in multiple formulations and often filled.
column10: widely used for its broad service temperature range in medical devices, gaskets, and culinary tools

column5: Polychloroprene is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic elastomeric rubbers; synthesised typically through emulsion polymerization of chloroprene
column9: it offers good weathering and ozone resistance.
column10: it is widely used in gaskets and wetsuits.

column5: nitrile butadiene rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic acrylonitrile–butadiene copolymer elastomers
column9: it can have tunable polarity and oil/fuel resistance
column10: it is widely used in oil/fuel resistance applicaitons such as seals, fuel hoses, and protective gloves

column5: Amorphous metal glass is glass that is characterized by a disordered, non-crystalline atomic structure, resembling a frozen liquid.
Iron-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is predominantly composed of iron.
Magnesium-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is primarily composed of magnesium, noted for its low density.
Zirconium-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is composed mainly of zirconium, valued for its corrosion resistance and strength.
Bioactive glass is a specialty glass that forms a biologically compatible hydroxycarbonate apatite (HCA) layer on its surface in physiological conditions
column9: enables bonding with bone tissue.

column5: Chalcogenide glass is a non‑silicate glass (generally non‑oxide) that contains one or more chalcogens
column9: Chalcogens such as sulfur, selenium, or tellurium as key constituents. Is valued particularly for infrared transparency.

column5: Chemically strengthened glass is a specialty glass that is treated via chemical processes to enhance its strength.
Conductive glass is functional glass that has been modified to exhibit electrical conductivity.

column4: ('glass' and ('part of' some (object and ('has function' some function))))
column5: Functional glass is advanced glass that is designed to perform specific roles beyond conventional optical applications.
column9: axiom is related to functional material

column5: Electrochromic glass is a specialty glass that can reversibly change its light transmission properties when an electrical voltage is applied.
Photochromic glass is a specialty glass that alters its optical properties in response to exposure to light.
Thermochromic glass is a specialty glass that changes its optical properties as a function of temperature.

column4: (glass and ('is specified output of' some 'ion-exchange hardening'))
column5: Ion-Exchanged glass is a form of chemically strengthened glass that is produced by exchanging ions to improve durability.
Magnetic glass is a specialty glass that exhibits intrinsic bulk magnetic behavior|Magnetic glass is functional glass that is modified to exhibit magnetic properties.
column9: Its composition and/or microstructure contains a significant population of magnetic species - typically transition‑metal or rare‑earth ions and/or magnetic nanophases - so that magnetic susceptibility/permeability/magnetization is a designed functional property of the glass.

column5: Non‑silicate glasses are glasses whose primary glass‑forming network is not based on SiO₂
column9: Based on other glass formers or non‑oxide systems (e.g., phosphate (P₂O₅)-based, fluoride-based, or chalcogenide (S/Se/Te)-based compositions).

column5: Borate glass is a non‑silicate glass based primarily on boron oxide (B₂O₃) as the glass‑forming network
column9: It is distinct from borosilicate glass because B₂O₃ is the primary network former here rather than an added co‑former in a silica‑based network.

column5: Borate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is formulated with borate compounds to promote biological interaction.
Germanate glass is a non-silicate glass that is composed primarily of germanium oxide, noted for its infrared transmission.
Phosphate glass is a non‑silicate glass based primarily on phosphorus pentoxide (P₂O₅)
column9: (P₂O₅) as the glass former (i.e., replacing SiO₂ as the network basis).

column5: Phosphate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is composed predominantly of phosphate compounds.
Optical glass is a specialty glass manufactured for optical components
column9: composition and processing chosen to achieve specified optical/mechanical parameters such as refractive index and dispersion.

column5: Crown glass is an optical glass that is characterized by its low dispersion and high clarity.
Flint glass is an optical glass that is distinguished by its high refractive index and dispersion.
Fused silica glass is an optical glass that is made from pure silica, prized for its high transparency and thermal stability.|Fused silica is a silicate glass that is essentially pure, amorphous SiO₂

column4: ('optical glass' and ('has characteristic' some 'non-linear optical property'))
column5: Nonlinear optical glass is functional glass that is engineered to display nonlinear optical responses under intense light.
Silicate glasses are glasses whose network is based primarily on silica (SiO₂)
Aluminosilicate glass is a silicate glass in which SiO₂ and Al₂O₃ are key structural units
column9: typically higher transformation/softening temperatures and improved mechanical/chemical performance compared with many common silicates

column5: Aluminosilicate gorilla glass is a chemically strengthened glass that is enhanced with an aluminosilicate composition for superior scratch resistance.
High-Temperature resistant glass is an aluminosilicate glass that is engineered to maintain stability at elevated temperatures.
Borosilicate glass is a silicate glass that uses boron trioxide (B₂O₃) as a major additional glass‑forming constituent
column9: characteristically low thermal expansion and high thermal/chemical resistance compared with soda‑lime glass.

column5: Cobalt-borosilicate glass is a magnetic glass that is formulated with cobalt to enhance its magnetic properties.
Iron-borosilicate glass is a magnetic glass that incorporates iron and borosilicate compounds to display magnetic behavior.
Pyrex-type glass is a form of borosilicate glass that is renowned for its high resistance to thermal shock.
Fused silica is a silicate glass that is essentially pure, amorphous SiO₂
column9: obtained by melting silica and cooling fast enough to avoid crystallization.
column10: often called fused quartz or vitreous silica

column5: Lead glass is a silicate glass in which lead(II) oxide (PbO) is incorporated in significant amounts
column9: increased refractive index and modified working properties relative to ordinary silicate glasses

column5: Barium glass is a form of lead glass that is modified with barium oxide to alter its optical properties.
Potash lead glass is a form of lead glass that utilizes potash as a flux in addition to lead oxide.
Silicate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is composed primarily of silicate compounds to facilitate bonding with biological tissue.
S53P4 Bioglass is a silicate-based bioactive glass formulated with a distinct composition for enhanced bioactivity.
45S5 Bioglass is a silicate-based bioactive glass with a specific composition known for its ability to bond with bone.
Soda‑lime glass is a silicate glass that is composed of about 70% silica (SiO₂) with soda (Na₂O) and lime (CaO)
column8: ('has part' some 'calcium oxide' and 'has part' some 'sodium hydroxide')
column9: soda (Na₂O) acting as a flux and lime (CaO) acting as a stabilizer
column10: widely used as common window and container glass.

column5: Specialty glasses are glasses engineered primarily for a targeted functional performance profile
Tellurite glass is a nonlinear optical glass that is formulated with tellurium oxide to achieve a high refractive index and nonlinear properties.

column4: (glass and ('is specified output of' some hardening))
column5: Toughened glass is a specialty glass that is mechanically treated to increase its strength and safety.
Laminated glass is a specialty glass that is composed of multiple bonded layers to improve safety and acoustic performance.
Fluoride glass is a non‑silicate glass made from metal fluorides (a non‑oxide glass family)
column9: Often used for photonics because certain compositions offer good infrared transmission and low phonon energies.

column5: Glass‑ceramics are inorganic, non‑metallic materials prepared by controlled crystallization of glasses via different processing methods; they contain at least one type of functional crystalline phase and a residual glass, and the crystallized volume fraction may vary from ppm to almost 100%.
column8: (('has quality' some 'crystal structure') and ('has part' some ('glass' and 'has role' some 'matrix role') and 'has part' some ('ceramic' and 'has role' some 'filler role')) )

column5: Leucite-Based glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that are non-clay ceramics containing leucite crystals to enhance thermal and mechanical properties.
Lithium disilicate glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that contain lithium disilicate crystals to provide high strength and aesthetic appeal.
column8: ('has part' some 'portion of lead' or 'has part' some 'portion of barium')
column9: Provides transparent attenuation of X‑rays (and, depending on design, gamma radiation).

column5: Transparent glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that are engineered to maintain optical transparency despite partial crystallization.

column5: Bioceramics are ceramics that are engineered to be compatible with biological systems.
Bioactive ceramics are bioceramics that interact with biological tissues to promote bonding or regeneration.
Bioresorbable ceramics are bioceramics that are designed to gradually be resorbed and replaced by natural tissue.
A composite material consisting of a polymer matrix and one or more reinforcement Materials.
A polymer-matrix composite, consisting of a polymer matrix reinforced with glass fibers
A polymer-matrix composite, consisting of a polymer matrix reinforced with carbon fibers.
A polymer-matrix composite, consisting of a polymer matrix reinforced with aramid (aromatic polyamide) fibers
A polymer-matrix composite, consisting of a polymer matrix reinforced with fibers derived from biological sources
A composite material consisting of a metal or alloy matrix and one or more reinforcement Materials.
A metal matrix composite, consisting of an aluminum or aluminum alloy matrix and one or more reinforcement materials.
column9: often used to improve stiffness/wear at low weight,

column5: A metal matrix composite, consisting of a titanium or titanium alloy matrix and one or more reinforcement materials.
column9: often chosen for elevated-temperature capability

column5: A metal matrix composite, consisting of a magnesium or magnesium alloy matrix and one or more reinforcement materials.
column9: known for its ultra-low density and improved specific strength.

column5: A metal matrix composite, consisting of a copper or copper alloy matrix and one or more reinforcement materials.
column9: often used for thermal management with high conductivity and tailored CTE (coefficient of thermal expansion)

column5: A composite material consisting of a ceramic matrix and one or more reinforcement Materials.
silicon carbide (SiC) Matrix Composites are non-oxide composite that are built with silicon carbide as the primary matrix reinforced by other ceramic phases.
Oxide-Oxide Composites are composite ceramic that consist entirely of oxide ceramic phases.
